1.brief: a son (as a builder of the family name), in the widest sense (of literal and figurative relationship, including grandson, subject, nation, quality or condition, etc., (like father or brother), etc.)
Korach, the name of two Edomites and three Israelites
properly, instrumental music; by implication, a poem set to notes
a sacred place or thing; rarely abstract, sanctity

2.brief: to have affection for (sexually or otherwise)
Jehovah, Jewish national name of God
an opening, i.e. door or gate
Tsijon (as a permanent capital), a mountain of Jerusalem
properly, the whole; hence, all, any or every (in the singular only, but often in a plural sense)
a residence (including a shepherd's hut, the lair of animals, figuratively, the grave; also the Temple); specifically, the Tabernacle (properly, its wooden walls)

3.brief: to be heavy, i.e. in a bad sense (burdensome, severe, dull) or in a good sense (numerous, rich, honorable; causatively, to make weighty (in the same two senses)
perhaps properly, to arrange; but used figuratively (of words), to speak; rarely (in a destructive sense) to subdue
a city (a place guarded by waking or a watch) in the widest sense (even of a mere encampment or post)

gods in the ordinary sense; but specifically used (in the plural thus, especially with the article) of the supreme God; occasionally applied by way of deference to magistrates; and sometimes as a superlative

4.brief: properly, to mark (so as to be recognized), i.e. to remember; by implication, to mention;  to be male
Rahab (i.e. boaster), an epithet of Egypt
Babel (i.e. Babylon), including Babylonia and the Babylonian empire

to know (properly, to ascertain by seeing); used in a great variety of senses, figuratively, literally, euphemistically and inferentially (including observation, care, recognition; and causatively, instruction, designation, punishment, etc.)
adverb or preposition, with (i.e. in conjunction with), in varied applications; specifically, equally with; often with prepositional prefix (and then usually unrepresented in English)
Cush (or Ethiopia), the name of a son of Ham, and of his territory; also of an Israelite
the masculine demonstrative pronoun, this or that
to bear young; causatively, to beget; medically, to act as midwife; specifically, to show lineage
there (transferring to time) then; often thither, or thence

5.brief: Tsijon (as a permanent capital), a mountain of Jerusalem
a man as an individual or a male person; often used as an adjunct to a more definite term (and in such cases frequently not expressed in translation)
a man as an individual or a male person; often used as an adjunct to a more definite term (and in such cases frequently not expressed in translation)
to bear young; causatively, to beget; medically, to act as midwife; specifically, to show lineage

he (she or it); only expressed when emphatic or without a verb; also (intensively) self, or (especially with the article) the same; sometimes (as demonstrative) this or that; occasionally (instead of copula) as or are

properly, to be erect (i.e. stand perpendicular); hence (causatively) to set up, in a great variety of applications, whether literal (establish, fix, prepare, apply), or figurative (appoint, render sure, proper or prosperous)
an elevation, i.e. (adj.) lofty (compar.); as title, the Supreme

6.brief: Jehovah, Jewish national name of God
properly, to score with a mark as a tally or record, i.e. (by implication) to inscribe, and also to enumerate; intensively, to recount, i.e. celebrate
to grave, by implication, to write (describe, inscribe, prescribe, subscribe)
a people (as a congregated unit); specifically, a tribe (as those of Israel); hence (collectively) troops or attendants; figuratively, a flock
the masculine demonstrative pronoun, this or that
to bear young; causatively, to beget; medically, to act as midwife; specifically, to show lineage
there (transferring to time) then; often thither, or thence

7.brief: properly, to bore, i.e. (by implication) to wound, to dissolve; figuratively, to profane (a person, place or thing), to break (one's word), to begin (as if by an 'opening wedge'); to play (the flute)
properly, the whole; hence, all, any or every (in the singular only, but often in a plural sense)
a fountain (also collectively), figuratively, a source (of satisfaction)
